title: 111_s1153
content: The Act titled "Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009" applies accident and health plans to eligible beneficiaries. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries of employees under accident and health plans. It also excludes amounts expended for medical care for employees and their dependents. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries of employees under accident and health plans. It also amends payroll taxes to include eligible beneficiaries with respect to the employee. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries of employees under accident and health plans, including dependents and eligible beneficiaries. It also includes eligible beneficiaries in payroll taxes with respect to the employee. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries of employees under accident and health plans, including dependents and eligible beneficiaries. It includes eligible beneficiaries in payroll taxes with respect to the employee. Amendments include expanding coverage to eligible beneficiaries and dependents, and updating terminology in the Code. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2009 expands coverage under the Internal Revenue Code to include payments made to employees or eligible beneficiaries that can be excluded from income. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 3. Expansion of dependency for deduction of health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. Expansion of dependency for deduction of health insurance costs for self-employed individuals under section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a taxpayer who is an employee to deduct insurance costs for medical care for themselves, their spouse, dependents, and certain other individuals. The amendment expands the eligibility for deducting health insurance costs under section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include individuals who meet specific requirements related to age, relationship to the taxpayer, and not being the spouse or bearing certain relationships to the taxpayer. The amendment expands health insurance cost deductions to include individuals meeting specific requirements, effective for taxable years after December 31, 2009. The amendment extends sick and accident benefits to eligible beneficiaries of a voluntary employees' beneficiary association and their dependents under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 5. FLEXIBLE SPENDING ARRANGEMENTS AND HEALTH REIMBURSEMENT. The Secretary of Treasury will issue guidance allowing medical expenses eligible for reimbursement from flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements to be reimbursed, even if they are for individuals who are not the employee's spouse or dependent but are eligible beneficiaries under the arrangement. The Act allows reimbursement of medical expenses from an employee's health reimbursement arrangement for eligible beneficiaries, even if they are not the employee's spouse or dependent. SEC. 6 extends qualified medical expenses from health savings accounts to include any qualified beneficiary, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
